title: Colorado WWII paratrooper dies after brief reunion with wife
title_page: Colorado WWII paratrooper dies after brief reunion with wife | Daily Mail Online
text:
A World War II paratrooper from Colorado who was initially denied permission to move into the same nursing home as his wife has passed away after their brief reunion.
Elmer Melchi, who had cancer, died in a hospice care center in Pueblo on Thursday - a week after his wife June Melchi, who has dementia, was brought to visit him there.
The veteran, who jumped into Normandy on D-Day and later was captured by the Germans in the Netherlands, passed away in his sleep at age 92, The Pueblo Chieftain reported.

During their last time together last week, the couple sang songs, held hands and kissed
Elmer Melchi (pictured), a World War II paratrooper from Colorado, who was initially denied permission to move into the same nursing home as his wife has passed away after their brief reunion just last week
'My dad went for his last jump,' one of Melchi's three sons, Gary, an Army veteran told the newspaper. 'He told me today, "I'm going."'
After his health worsened on New Year's Eve, the Veterans Administration denied the family's request to allow him to spend his final days with his wife who was at University Park Care Center because it was not a VA-sanctioned facility.
At the time, an anonymous donor had offered to pay for 10 days of care for Elmer Melchi at the nursing home after learning of the couple's plight.
However, the VA later gave permission, but Garry Melchi said his father's health never improved enough to allow him to move, The Pueblo Chieftain reported.
Instead, the couple was reunited when June Melchi was taken to Sangre de Cristo Hospice for the sweet reunion last Wednesday.
While his wife no longer remembered her husband's name, she was happy to be with him as they sang, held hands and kissed during what became their last time together, according to the newspaper.
The couple met in England and married in 1945.

The veteran, who jumped into Normandy on D-Day and later was captured by the Germans in the Netherlands, passed away in his sleep at age 92 at Sangre de Cristo Hospice (pictured)
Garry Melchi previously said his father was captured during Operation Market Garden, shot while trying to escape a POW camp and finally freed after the Russians liberated the camp.
He said his father walked across Germany and France and got on a boat to go to England, where the future June Melchi thought he was dead.
'He only had one thing on his mind - get to my mom,' Garry Melchi said.
He said his father drove to the nursing home to see his 89-year-old mother four times a week until his health worsened on New Year's Eve.
